trial_identification.studytitle: The impact of physical activity on fatigue and quality of life in lung cancer patients.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The impact of physical activty on fatigue and quality of life in non-resectable thoracic lung cancer patients.
trial_identification.trialacronym: PAL (Physical Activity in Lung cancer patients)
trial_identification.secondaryid: Phyiscal Activity in Lung Cancer Patients

interventions.interventions: Participants randomised to the intervention group will take part in an 8-week personalised physical activity program. The type (e.g. aerobic, resistance or flexibility), and intensity of the sessions will be tailored to the fitness level and preferences of the individual participant. The physical activity sessions are for 1 hour / week for 8 weeks and also include a behavioural support session. The behavioural support sessions include topics such as goal setting, plainng, motivation and time management. The physical activity sessions are conducted face-to-face with an exercise physiologist or physiotherapist. They can be one-on-one or in a small group, depending on the preference of the participant. The behavioural sessions can be either face-to-face or over the phone with a member of the research team.
interventions.comparator: Participants randomised to the control group will receive standard of care treatment for their condition. They will be assessed at the same time points as the intervention group (i.e Baseline, 2, 4 and 6 months).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Self-reported fatigue (at 2 months) Instrument: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Fatigue (FACT-F) subscale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self-reported fatigue (at 4 and 6 months). Instrument: FACT-F subscale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 4 and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Health-related Quality of Life Instrument: European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer-Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC-QLQ) -C30 and LC13-lung subscale.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety and Depression. Instrument: General Health Questionnaire-12
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.
At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Sleep. Instrument: Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.
At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical activity attitudes. Instrument: Social Cognitive Determinants of Exercise Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived Cognitive Function. Instrument: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Cognitive (FACT-Cog), v3
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Breathing Difficulties. Instrument: Shortness of Breath Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.
At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical activity behaviour. Instrument: Active Australia Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical Fitness. Instruments: Senior's Fitness Test, dynamometer
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Ability to perform everyday activities. Instrument: Activities of Daily Living Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.
At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Glasgow Prognostic Score. Instrument: Full blood count and C-Reactive Protein analysis
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Eastern Co-operative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status. Instrument: Clinician, assessor and patient-rated
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 2, 4, and 6 months from baseline.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Diagnosis of non-resectable invasive lung cancer, eg non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) or small cell lung cancer (SCLC). 2. Completion of treatment at least 4 weeks prior to study involvement for patients with Stage III NSCLC or Limited SCLC. 3. Age of a least 18 years. 4. Medically fit to participate on a physical activity programme. 5. Ability to complete study questionnaires in English. 6. Give written informed consent. 7. Completion of screening questionnaires within 14 days of registration.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status of 3 or more. 2. Pre-existing significant comorbidities that preclude participation in a physical activity programme. 3. Life expectancy of less than 6 months. 4. Insufficient English fluency to complete questionnaires. 5. Inability to complete baseline exercise test done prior to randomisation

trial_design.concealment: Patients are randomly assigned to the intervention or control group using the National Health and Medical Research Coucnil (NHMRC) Clinical Trial Centreâ€™s Randomisation Interactive Voice Response System.
trial_design.sequence: The study will be stratified for disease stage (limited vs. advanced), performance status (ECOG PS 0 -1 vs. 2), and centre.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Sydney Cancer Centre Concord Repatriation and General Hospital Hospital Rd. Concord, NSW 2139

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 1221 S. MoPac Expressway, Suite 350 Austin, Texas 78746

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
This study looks at the impact of physical activity on fatigue and quality of life in people with thoracic lung cancer.
Who is it for? You may be eligible to join this study if you have invasive thoracic cancer which is not suitable for surgical removal.
Trial details: Participants will be divided into two groups. One group (the control group) will receive standard care for 6 months. The other group will take part in a physical activity program, with behavioural support for 8 weeks in addition to standard care. Study aims: To compare self-reported fatigue levels and quality of life in the two groups to determine the effects of exercise.
